narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: N/A
Take home MATLAB assignments
Lectures were both live virtual and recorded.

The live lectures were also recorded, so they came really handy for referencing back when doing the homework or tests. The course also had "virtual labs" which were more like independent assignments that we completed on MatLab.
recorded lecture
youtube
Live virtual lecture with the option to watch the recorded lectures after

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a little about many different topics that related to signal processing, information theory, and networking.
Basic systems, networks, communication aspect of electrical engineering
I learned basic probability, how to encode and decode signals, and how these signals can fit into a larger system. I would say the breadth of topics covered in this course is pretty wide.

I learned a lot about encoding, bit processing, and how to use MatLab. The signals and Fourier series unit was tough, but it was interesting information and I'm glad I got the exposure.  The class also had a lot of large picture system information in the lectures that I found really cool, a little difficult to understand, but mostly cool.
Overview of some of the math required for information theory and signal processing, including probability, convolution, Fourier transforms, etc.
I learned about techniques in encoding information, Fourier series and transforms, estimation techniques, such as hypothesis testing and regression, and network architecture.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course material was fascinating and I enjoyed the lectures. I wish that the whiteboard function on Zoom could have been used more specifically when it came to the convolution unit. It was really challenging to learn how to solve complicated math problems on powerpoint.

Lecture notes seem disparate from the lecture slides and content so it was a bit hard to follow, ended up just using the PowerPoint slides
MATLAB programs were fun but doing it alone did not have the collaborative environment of a STEM lab unfortunately.

Strengths: Professor Hu was very flexible and always willing to help us out. The material was really interesting.
Weaknesses: The PowerPoint format of the lectures was sometimes hard to follow. I think it would be good if there were some parts of lecture (like practice problems) that were filled out on an iPad in class in real time. The take-home exams took much much longer than the suggested time. The final exam in particular took me about two (focused) days to complete, and the suggested time was 3 hours.

Dr. Hu was extremely accommodating to student input, so that was a huge strength. She would ask us for ideal midterm and final dates and time frames, as well as make the homework graded for credit to ensure that we gave it our best efforts. Her feedback on midterms was also vital for learning and correcting future mistakes. She would also have a review of the past lecture at the start of every new lecture which I found very helpful. 

The signals and Fourier series unit could maybe have used more walked through examples, but overall the course was strong. The only weakness was at times a difficulty showcasing examples over Zoom, it was a new switch and I understand that the technological support from school wasn't there so I get the struggle.
Doing more examples after the introduction of each unit especially with Fourier d and the like would have been helpful.

Strengths: the material was extremely interesting, and Professor Hu was very understanding and responsive to students' needs
Weaknesses: sometimes the lectures could be very confusing with all the theoretical math/symbols. It also may be helpful to have some sort of tablet to use like a whiteboard in the future.

The professor was very organized and she made herself very accessible to students through the use of GroupMe. I think the course could have been improved if there was a way for the professor to write on the presentation slides during lecture.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Office hours and peer tutoring were very helpful.
The virtual lectures were okay, homework and labs felt comparable to my previous engineering class before COVID but did not feel very engaged with the classmates throughout.
I think using an iPad to write out some of the notes and having some of them typed out beforehand would be easier to follow than the PowerPoint format.

I think recording the live lectures was really useful. I would often go back to them for the homework. The two formats of information, the pre-written notes, and the lecture slides were also helpful when trying to understand the material. If I didn't get a topic in lectures, the notes were there to supplement the information. I do wish the professors would have received their iPads, it was a struggle to properly showcase some of the math and examples with only a laptop.
The tick based grading for labs and psets were helpful

Personally, I liked having live lectures because of the schedule it created for me.  I also definitely appreciated having take-home exams, which reduced some of the stress.  One thing that could be improved would be to have a tablet and use it like a whiteboard during lecture, which would save a lot of time used to try drawing things using a computer mouse.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: If they were interested in the topic, yes.
Yes, I would recommend this course to anyone interesting in signal processing and information theory.
Required for EE majors, else take it if you are interested in the systems (non hardware) portions of EE. Might be helpful for further studies in statistics or machine learning.

I would recommend this course to another student. The concepts I learned in this class are applicable in many other classes, and they're really interesting. One of the great things about this class is that there are so many topics covered that if you are pretty much bound to find something that you really enjoy.

Yes. It was a pretty interesting course. It covered a lot of cool EE system topics. I don't know how much I fully understand everything, but at least in terms of exposure to the concepts, the course was solid.
no please don't grade assignments with checks
Yes, overall I liked it and definitely learned a lot.
